bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Edward Gilbert was drafted into the United States Army in June of 1942. The Wethersfield, Connecticut native served overseas in the 2nd Engineer Boat and Shore Regiment in the South Pacific. He received his basic training at Fort Bragg in North Carolina and his amphibious training at Camp Edwards, Massachusetts, Washburn Island, Massachusetts, Martha’s Vineyard, Massachusetts, and Cairns, Australia. Edward served in the Philippines and Australia as the coxswain (driver) of Landing Craft 838. Achieving the rank of Technician 4th Grade, Sergeant Edward received the Good Conduct Ribbon and the Asiatic Pacific Ribbon with Arrowhead. He was honorably discharged in October of 1945

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This collection details Edward Gilbert’s military experiences during his enlistment in World War II. A taped interview was conducted on June 17, 2004 at Central Connecticut State University by Eileen Hurst. Along with Edward’s taped interview the collection contains reproductions of personal documents, publications and photographs. The materials provide evidence of the development of the U.S. Army’s “ship to shore” or amphibious landing crafts, enemy activity and engagement, amphibious training, and crew responsibilities.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: The folder contains an article published in the Falmouth Enterprise titled “Cape Cod as the Cradle of Invasion.” The story, a component of the 14 part series from The Story of Camp Edwards from Scrub Pines to Medical Center, describes the development of the U.S. Army’s amphibious training, techniques and landing craft on the beaches of Cape Cod.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: A U.S. Army recruiting advertisement published in the New York Times. The ad espouses the glory and thrill of Sea Taxis and the Army Engineer’s Amphibian Command.
